description: SPM Knowledge Base Expansion Phase 3 - Completing 1,000+ cards

cards.definition: A reduction in quota granted to reps due to qualifying circumstances like territory changes, leave of absence, or market disruptions.
cards.whyItMatters: Maintains fairness when circumstances beyond rep control affect their ability to achieve quota.
cards.howItWorks: Qualifying event occurs → Request submitted → Approval obtained → Quota reduced proportionally.
cards.example: Rep on 3-month medical leave gets 25% annual quota relief. $2M quota reduced to $1.5M.

cards.definition: The structured process of distributing company targets down through organizational levels.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures quotas sum to company targets and are fairly distributed.
cards.howItWorks: Company target → Region allocation → District allocation → Team allocation → Individual rep.
cards.example: $100M company → $40M West Region → $10M SF District → $2.5M per team → $500K per rep.

cards.definition: A quota target set for a calendar or fiscal quarter rather than annually.
cards.whyItMatters: Matches business rhythms and enables more frequent performance assessment.
cards.howItWorks: Annual quota divided into quarters → May be equal or seasonally weighted → Attainment measured quarterly.

cards.definition: Modifying quota distribution across periods to reflect predictable business patterns.
cards.whyItMatters: Aligns quotas with realistic sales patterns, improving fairness and accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze historical patterns → Identify seasonal trends → Weight quotas accordingly → Validate totals.
cards.example: Retail software: Q4 gets 35% of annual quota vs. 25% standard due to holiday buying.

cards.definition: An individual metric that makes up part of a rep's overall quota (e.g., new business, renewal, product-specific).
cards.whyItMatters: Enables balanced performance measurement across multiple business priorities.
cards.howItWorks: Define components → Weight by importance → Set targets for each → Measure independently → Roll up to total.
cards.example: Total quota $1M: New business $600K (60%), Renewals $300K (30%), Services $100K (10%).

cards.definition: A quota for managers based on the aggregate performance of their direct reports.
cards.whyItMatters: Aligns manager incentives with team success rather than individual deals.
cards.howItWorks: Sum of direct report quotas (possibly adjusted) = manager rollup quota. May include buffer or stretch.
cards.example: 8 AEs with $500K each = $4M team quota. Manager rollup = $4.2M (5% stretch).

cards.definition: The average commission rate earned across all transactions or attainment levels.
cards.whyItMatters: Useful for cost modeling and comparing plan economics across different structures.
cards.howItWorks: Total Commission Earned ÷ Total Credited Revenue = Effective Rate.
cards.example: Rep earned $50K commission on $1M revenue. Effective rate = 5%, even though rates varied by deal.

cards.definition: A composite performance score combining multiple quota components according to their weights.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides single performance metric when reps have multiple quota components.
cards.howItWorks: Each component attainment × weight → Sum weighted attainments = total weighted attainment.
cards.example: New business 120% at 60% weight + Renewal 90% at 40% weight = (1.2×0.6) + (0.9×0.4) = 72% + 36% = 108%.

cards.definition: A portion of earned commission withheld pending verification of deal terms or conditions.
cards.whyItMatters: Protects against overpayments on deals that may cancel or modify.
cards.howItWorks: Commission calculated → Percentage held back → Released after verification period → Or clawed back if issue.
cards.example: 20% holdback on enterprise deals until contract fully executed. Release after 30 days if no issues.

cards.definition: Commission treatment for contracts spanning multiple years, which may be recognized upfront, annually, or proportionally.
cards.whyItMatters: Significant cash flow and quota impact depending on recognition method.
cards.howItWorks: Options: Full value at signing, annual recognition, TCV with discount, ACV only.
cards.example: 3-year $300K deal: Option A - $300K upfront. Option B - $100K/year. Option C - $270K TCV (10% discount).

cards.definition: Commission paid for renewing existing customer contracts, typically at a lower rate than new business.
cards.whyItMatters: Balances incentive for new acquisition vs. retention of existing revenue.
cards.howItWorks: Customer renews → Renewal value credited → Lower rate applied → May have uplift/downsell adjustments.
cards.example: New business: 10% rate. Renewal at same value: 4% rate. Renewal with expansion: 6% on expansion, 4% on base.

cards.definition: Commission paid on incremental revenue from existing customers above their base contract.
cards.whyItMatters: Drives land-and-expand strategy by incentivizing customer growth.
cards.howItWorks: Identify expansion value (new revenue - base) → Apply expansion rate → Credit to appropriate rep.
cards.example: Customer base $100K, expands to $150K. Expansion commission: 8% × $50K = $4K.

cards.definition: Additional commission paid to managers based on their team's performance.
cards.whyItMatters: Aligns manager incentives with team success.
cards.howItWorks: Team revenue × override rate = manager override payment. May apply to specific deal types.
cards.example: Manager gets 1% override on all team revenue. Team closes $10M → $100K override to manager.

cards.definition: SEC rule requiring public companies to recover erroneously awarded incentive compensation from executives following restatements.
cards.whyItMatters: Mandatory for public companies; affects executive incentive plan design.
cards.howItWorks: Financial restatement occurs → Identify overpayments → Calculate recovery amount → Recover from executives.
cards.example: Restatement reduces revenue → Executive bonus recalculated → $200K overpayment recovered over 24 months.

cards.definition: Accounting standards (ASC 606) governing when and how revenue is recognized, which may differ from commission timing.
cards.whyItMatters: Commission timing may not align with revenue recognition; creates accrual complexity.
cards.howItWorks: Revenue recognized per ASC 606 → Commission may be earned on booking → Accrual adjustments needed.
cards.example: 3-year deal booked, commission paid upfront, but revenue recognized ratably. Accrual carries commission cost.

cards.definition: An alternative control implemented when ideal segregation of duties cannot be achieved.
cards.whyItMatters: Maintains control effectiveness when organizational constraints prevent optimal design.
cards.howItWorks: Identify control gap → Design compensating control → Document rationale → Test effectiveness.
cards.example: Small team can't separate calculation from approval. Compensating control: Monthly independent reconciliation.

cards.definition: A formal request to deviate from standard compensation policy for a specific situation.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables flexibility while maintaining control and documentation.
cards.howItWorks: Request submitted → Business case documented → Appropriate approval obtained → Time-limited exception granted.
cards.example: Exception request: Pay commission on partner deal outside normal crediting rules. Requires VP approval.

cards.definition: The committed timeframe for responding to and resolving compensation inquiries or disputes.
cards.whyItMatters: Sets expectations and ensures timely resolution of rep concerns.
cards.howItWorks: Inquiry submitted → Acknowledgment within X hours → Resolution within Y days → Escalation if exceeded.
cards.example: Inquiry SLA: Acknowledge within 24 hours, resolve within 5 business days. Escalation to manager if exceeded.

cards.definition: The ratio of total pipeline value to remaining quota, indicating likelihood of hitting target.
cards.whyItMatters: Key indicator of forecast risk; low coverage signals potential miss.
cards.howItWorks: Pipeline Coverage = Total Qualified Pipeline ÷ Remaining Quota. Target typically 3-4x.
cards.example: Remaining quota $500K, pipeline $2M. Coverage = 4x. Healthy if win rate is 25%+.

cards.definition: The average time from opportunity creation to close, measured in days.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for capacity planning, forecasting, and identifying process issues.
cards.howItWorks: Sum of (Close Date - Create Date) for won deals ÷ Number of deals = Average cycle length.
cards.example: Enterprise deals: Average 120 days. SMB: Average 30 days. Track by segment and deal size.

cards.definition: The mean value of closed deals over a given period.
cards.whyItMatters: Key input for capacity planning and sales velocity calculations.
cards.howItWorks: Total Closed Revenue ÷ Number of Closed Deals = Average Deal Size.
cards.example: Q4: $5M total from 50 deals. ADS = $100K. Compare to Q3 ADS of $90K (11% increase).

cards.definition: The accuracy of deals marked as 'Commit' in closing within the forecasted period.
cards.whyItMatters: Measures forecast reliability for deals reps are highly confident will close.
cards.howItWorks: Track deals in Commit category → Count how many close in period → Calculate close rate.
cards.example: 10 deals in Commit, 8 closed in quarter. Commit accuracy = 80%. Target >90%.

cards.definition: An AI model that predicts which customers are at risk of not renewing.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables proactive intervention to save at-risk revenue.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze usage patterns, support tickets, engagement → Model identifies risk factors → Score customers → Alert CSMs.
cards.example: Customer X: Low login frequency, support escalation, invoice delay. Churn risk: 78%. Trigger intervention.

cards.definition: A comprehensive platform combining ICM, territory management, quota planning, and analytics.
cards.whyItMatters: Single platform reduces integration complexity and improves data consistency.
cards.howItWorks: Unified data model → Integrated modules → Shared reporting → Single vendor relationship.
cards.example: Varicent SPM: Territory planning, quota management, incentive calculation, analytics all in one platform.

cards.definition: A system component that calculates commission expense accruals for financial reporting.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for accurate financial statements and ASC 606 compliance.
cards.howItWorks: Earned commissions calculated → Accrual journal entries generated → Reconciled to payments → Adjusted as needed.
cards.example: Monthly close: Accrue $2M earned commissions → Credit accrual liability → Reverse when paid.

cards.definition: The connection between ICM systems and payroll for disbursing commission payments.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures accurate, timely payment of earned commissions.
cards.howItWorks: ICM calculates commissions → Generates payroll file → Transmits to payroll system → Payroll processes → Funds disbursed.
cards.example: Monthly commission file: Employee ID, earning code, amount. Submitted by 15th, paid on 25th.

cards.definition: Commission calculations triggered immediately when transactions occur rather than in periodic batches.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides reps immediate visibility into earnings, improving motivation and reducing inquiries.
cards.howItWorks: Transaction received → Calculation triggered → Results updated → Rep notified/visible immediately.
cards.example: Deal closes in CRM → ICM calculates commission within minutes → Rep sees earnings on dashboard.

cards.definition: How a company's compensation compares to market rates for similar roles.
cards.whyItMatters: Determines ability to attract and retain sales talent.
cards.howItWorks: Benchmark against market data → Identify positioning (percentile) → Adjust if misaligned.
cards.example: Current OTE at 45th percentile. Losing talent to competitors. Recommendation: Move to 65th percentile.

cards.definition: The degree to which a compensation plan drives intended behaviors and business outcomes.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures compensation investment delivers expected returns.
cards.howItWorks: Define desired behaviors → Measure before/after → Correlate to plan changes → Adjust as needed.
cards.example: New accelerator drove 15% increase in above-quota performance at 8% cost increase. ROI positive.

cards.definition: Ensuring compensation is fair and free from discrimination across demographic groups.
cards.whyItMatters: Legal requirement and ethical imperative; affects retention and culture.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze pay by demographic factors → Identify unexplained gaps → Remediate → Monitor ongoing.
cards.example: Analysis shows female AEs earn 8% less than male peers controlling for tenure/performance. Remediation plan initiated.

cards.definition: The graphical representation of how earnings vary with performance levels.
cards.whyItMatters: Visual tool for understanding and communicating plan economics.
cards.howItWorks: Plot performance (X) vs. earnings (Y) → Shows floors, thresholds, accelerators, caps.
cards.example: Linear curve to 100%, 2x slope from 100-150%, flat above 150% (cap).

cards.definition: The statistical distribution of rep performance against quota.
cards.whyItMatters: Indicates quota fairness and identifies plan design opportunities.
cards.howItWorks: Calculate attainment for all reps → Plot distribution → Analyze shape, median, spread.
cards.example: Distribution: 10% <70%, 60% at 70-130%, 30% >130%. Suggests quotas may be too easy.

cards.definition: The process of identifying, engaging, and managing individuals affected by compensation changes.
cards.whyItMatters: Success depends on stakeholder support; opposition can derail projects.
cards.howItWorks: Identify stakeholders → Assess influence/impact → Develop engagement plan → Execute → Monitor.
cards.example: Stakeholder map: Executive sponsor (high influence), Sales managers (high impact), Finance (approval authority).

cards.definition: A structured plan for informing stakeholders about compensation changes.
cards.whyItMatters: Poor communication breeds resistance; good communication builds support.
cards.howItWorks: Define audiences → Craft messages → Select channels → Schedule delivery → Gather feedback.
cards.example: Week 1: Executive announcement. Week 2: Manager deep-dive. Week 3: Rep town hall. Week 4: 1:1 plan reviews.

cards.definition: Measurements tracking how effectively users are utilizing the new compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Adoption indicates change success; low adoption signals issues.
cards.howItWorks: Track logins, feature usage, inquiry rates → Compare to targets → Intervene if low.
cards.example: Month 1: 70% logged in, 40% viewed statement, 5 inquiries. Month 3: 95% logged in, 80% viewed, 2 inquiries.

cards.definition: A detailed plan for transitioning from the old system to the new system.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical period requiring careful orchestration to avoid disruption.
cards.howItWorks: Define cutover steps → Assign owners → Set timing → Execute → Verify → Rollback if needed.
cards.example: Friday 6pm: Freeze old system. Saturday: Run final calculations. Sunday: Validate. Monday: Go-live new system.

cards.definition: Legal exposure from disputes over commission payments, often amplified by state wage laws.
cards.whyItMatters: Commission disputes can result in penalties, attorneys fees, and class actions.
cards.howItWorks: Rep claims unpaid commission → Files complaint or lawsuit → Company must defend → Penalties if liable.
cards.example: California class action: 200 reps claim earned commissions not timely paid. Potential liability: $5M+ with waiting time penalties.

cards.definition: Penalties assessed for failure to timely pay earned commissions, significant in states like California.
cards.whyItMatters: Penalties can exceed original commission amount; creates significant liability.
cards.howItWorks: Commission earned but not timely paid → Penalty accrues daily → Caps at 30 days wages (CA).
cards.example: California: Daily wages continue for up to 30 days after termination if final pay not timely. $500/day × 30 = $15K penalty.

cards.definition: A formal change to an existing commission plan, which may require rep consent or have timing restrictions.
cards.whyItMatters: Improper amendments can be unenforceable; proper process protects both parties.
cards.howItWorks: Identify change needed → Draft amendment → Legal review → Communicate → Obtain acknowledgment → Implement.
cards.example: Mid-year rate change: New amendment drafted, legal approved, rep acknowledgment obtained, effective next month.

cards.definition: The legal determination of whether a sales person is an employee or independent contractor.
cards.whyItMatters: Misclassification creates significant tax liability and penalties.
cards.howItWorks: Apply classification tests (economic reality, ABC test) → Determine status → Apply appropriate treatment.
cards.example: 1099 sales contractor later reclassified as employee. Company owes back taxes, overtime, benefits.

cards.definition: Requirements for how long commission plan documents and records must be retained.
cards.whyItMatters: Failure to retain creates legal exposure; enables defense of disputes.
cards.howItWorks: Identify retention requirements (varies by jurisdiction) → Implement retention policy → Secure storage → Destruction after period.
cards.example: Retain commission records 7 years from payment date. Plan documents indefinitely. Secure digital archive.

cards.definition: The process of determining which sales rep owns which customer accounts.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear ownership prevents conflicts and ensures coverage.
cards.howItWorks: Define assignment rules → Apply to accounts → Handle exceptions → Document ownership.
cards.example: Rule: Accounts in ZIP codes 94xxx assigned to SF territory. Override: Key account XYZ assigned to Strategic AE.

cards.definition: Adjusting territory boundaries to ensure equitable opportunity and workload across reps.
cards.whyItMatters: Imbalanced territories create unfair quotas and suboptimal coverage.
cards.howItWorks: Measure territory potential → Identify imbalances → Adjust boundaries → Rebalance quotas.
cards.example: Territory A: $50M potential, Territory B: $20M. Rebalance to $35M each by moving accounts.

cards.definition: The organizational structure defining reporting relationships in the sales organization.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for rollup calculations, reporting, and approval workflows.
cards.howItWorks: Define levels → Assign reps to managers → Map territories to regions → Update as changes occur.
cards.example: Rep → Team Lead → District Manager → Regional VP → CRO. Each level has rollup quota and override.

cards.definition: Managing changes to sales data (territories, quotas, hierarchies) with specific effective dates.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables accurate historical reporting and retroactive calculations.
cards.howItWorks: Changes recorded with effective date → System uses date logic → Historical and future states maintained.
cards.example: Rep moves territories March 15. System credits old territory through March 14, new territory from March 15.

cards.definition: A commission adjustment applied to a prior period, typically due to data corrections or policy clarifications.
cards.whyItMatters: Common occurrence requiring clear policy and process.
cards.howItWorks: Issue identified → Correct calculation determined → Adjustment processed → Paid in current period → Documented.
cards.example: Q1 deal credited to wrong rep. Q3 correction: Credit transferred, original rep has clawback, correct rep gets payment.

cards.definition: Payment of commission before the normal payment date or before the commission is fully earned.
cards.whyItMatters: May be used for recruiting or special situations; creates recovery complexity.
cards.howItWorks: Advance authorized → Paid early → Tracked against earnings → Recovered from future commissions if unearned.
cards.example: Signing bonus structured as commission advance: $50K paid at hire, earned over 12 months, clawed back if rep leaves early.

cards.definition: Limiting commission earnings above a certain level, either per deal or per period.
cards.whyItMatters: Controls windfall risk but may demotivate top performers.
cards.howItWorks: Define cap level → Monitor earnings → Stop accrual at cap → Reset next period.
cards.example: Per-deal cap: 3x average commission. Period cap: 300% of target incentive. Annual cap: $500K total.
bestPractices: Set high enough to be rare

cards.definition: A matrix defining who can approve what types and amounts of compensation decisions.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures appropriate oversight of compensation decisions.
cards.howItWorks: Define decision types → Set approval thresholds → Assign approval authority → Document and enforce.
cards.example: Exception <$10K: Manager. $10-50K: Director. >$50K: VP. Plan changes: SGCC approval.

cards.definition: Periodic testing to verify that compensation controls are operating effectively.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for SOX compliance; identifies control gaps before they become issues.
cards.howItWorks: Select sample → Test control operation → Document results → Remediate deficiencies.
cards.example: Q2 control test: Sample 25 commission calculations. Verify each has proper approval. Finding: 2/25 missing approval. Remediate.

cards.definition: Controls ensuring compensation data is handled in compliance with privacy regulations.
cards.whyItMatters: Compensation data is sensitive personal data; mishandling creates legal liability.
cards.howItWorks: Identify personal data → Implement access controls → Encrypt at rest/transit → Enable data subject rights.
cards.example: GDPR compliance: EU rep data encrypted, access logged, retention limited, delete on request.

cards.definition: Comparing individual rep performance against peers, cohorts, or standards.
cards.whyItMatters: Identifies coaching opportunities and validates quota fairness.
cards.howItWorks: Define peer groups → Calculate metrics → Rank and compare → Identify outliers → Take action.
cards.example: Rep A at 85% attainment. Peer average 105%. Tenure-matched peers at 95%. Gap indicates coaching need.

cards.definition: Analysis of how commission payouts are distributed across the sales organization.
cards.whyItMatters: Indicates plan health and identifies potential issues.
cards.howItWorks: Calculate payouts by rep → Plot distribution → Analyze shape → Compare to expected.
cards.example: Distribution shows: Top 10% earning 50% of total commissions. Indicates high performer concentration.

cards.definition: The percentage of reps achieving 100% or more of quota.
cards.whyItMatters: Key indicator of quota setting quality; too high or low signals issues.
cards.howItWorks: Count reps at/above quota ÷ Total reps = Achievement rate.
cards.example: Q4: 35 of 50 reps hit quota. Achievement rate = 70%. Target range typically 60-75%.

cards.definition: The ability for users to create their own reports and analyses without IT involvement.
cards.whyItMatters: Reduces reporting bottlenecks and enables faster insights.
cards.howItWorks: Pre-built data models → Drag-drop interface → User creates reports → Shares with others.
cards.example: Sales manager creates custom report: Team attainment by product line, filters to Q4, exports to Excel.

cards.definition: System capabilities for storing, versioning, and managing compensation plan documents.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for compliance; enables retrieval for disputes and audits.
cards.howItWorks: Upload documents → Version automatically → Link to rep records → Enable search and retrieval.
cards.example: All signed plan acknowledgments stored in system, linked to rep profile, searchable by date/name/plan.

cards.definition: The allocation of target incentive across different compensation components.
cards.whyItMatters: Determines which behaviors are most rewarded.
cards.howItWorks: Total incentive divided among components → Higher weight = higher focus.
cards.example: Target incentive $100K: New business 60% ($60K), Renewal 30% ($30K), MBO 10% ($10K).

cards.definition: The process of determining at what performance level commission payments begin.
cards.whyItMatters: Balances minimum performance expectations with motivation.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze historical distribution → Set floor at appropriate level → Determine cumulative vs. non-cumulative.
cards.example: Analysis shows 90% of reps exceed 60% attainment. Set floor at 50% to be achievable but meaningful.

cards.definition: The process of determining how and when commission rates increase for above-quota performance.
cards.whyItMatters: Key driver of over-performance; significant cost and motivation impact.
cards.howItWorks: Determine trigger point → Set rate increase → Model cost scenarios → Test motivation impact.
cards.example: Options: 1.5x rate above 100%, or tiered (1.3x at 100-120%, 1.5x at 120-150%, 2x above 150%).

cards.definition: The process of setting up compensation rules and structures in the ICM platform.
cards.whyItMatters: Configuration quality determines calculation accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: Translate plan documents to system rules → Configure components → Test → Validate.
cards.example: Configure: Rate tables, crediting rules, quota assignments, payment schedules, calculation sequence.

cards.definition: Creating comprehensive test cases to validate compensation calculations.
cards.whyItMatters: Thorough testing prevents payment errors and builds confidence.
cards.howItWorks: Identify scenarios → Create test data → Define expected results → Execute → Compare.
cards.example: Test scenarios: Standard deal, split credit, accelerator crossing, clawback, multi-period, new hire ramp.

cards.definition: The legal distinction between commission that has been fully earned and commission that is contingent.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for termination pay; earned commissions must be paid.
cards.howItWorks: Define earning criteria → Document in plan → Apply consistently → Pay earned amounts.
cards.example: Commission earned when: Deal closes AND payment received AND chargeback period expires.

cards.definition: The employment doctrine allowing either party to end the relationship at any time without cause.
cards.whyItMatters: Plan changes and terminations must respect at-will status while honoring earned compensation.
cards.howItWorks: Preserve at-will language → Don't create implied contracts → Pay earned amounts → Document everything.
cards.example: Plan document states: 'This plan does not create employment contract. Employment remains at-will.'

cards.definition: Tax implications of paying commissions to employees in multiple countries.
cards.whyItMatters: Incorrect treatment creates tax liabilities for company and employee.
cards.howItWorks: Determine tax residency → Apply local tax rules → Proper withholding → Reporting compliance.
cards.example: US company paying UK rep: Determine PE status, apply UK PAYE withholding, report to HMRC.

cards.definition: A model calculating the revenue-generating capacity of the sales organization.
cards.whyItMatters: Foundation for headcount planning and quota allocation.
cards.howItWorks: Productive headcount × productivity rate × time = capacity. Factor ramp and attrition.
cards.example: 50 fully ramped AEs × $2M productivity = $100M capacity. Add 10 new hires at 50% = $10M more.

cards.definition: The number of direct reports a sales manager supervises.
cards.whyItMatters: Affects management effectiveness and cost structure.
cards.howItWorks: Total reps ÷ Number of managers = Average span. Target varies by role complexity.
cards.example: Inside sales: 10-12 per manager. Enterprise: 5-7 per manager. SDR: 8-10 per manager.

cards.definition: The process of determining which rep(s) receive quota credit for a transaction.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate crediting is foundation of commission calculation.
cards.howItWorks: Apply crediting rules → Match to rep/territory → Handle exceptions → Document assignment.
cards.example: Deal in SF ZIP code → Assigned to SF territory owner. Partner involved → Split credit per partner rules.

cards.definition: The time period over which commissions are calculated and paid (monthly, quarterly).
cards.whyItMatters: Affects cash flow for reps and company; influences behavior.
cards.howItWorks: Transactions accumulated over period → Period closes → Calculations finalized → Payment processed.
cards.example: Monthly commission period: Transactions through last day of month, paid by 15th of following month.

cards.definition: A review of commission calculations and payments to verify accuracy and compliance.
cards.whyItMatters: Identifies errors before they become material; demonstrates control effectiveness.
cards.howItWorks: Select sample → Verify calculations → Check documentation → Report findings → Remediate issues.
cards.example: Quarterly audit: Sample 50 payments, verify against source data, check approvals, report 3 discrepancies found.

cards.definition: The approval process required before commission payments are released.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical control to prevent unauthorized payments.
cards.howItWorks: Calculations complete → Review and approve → Generate payment file → Authorize release → Process payment.
cards.example: Monthly process: Comp Admin prepares, Manager reviews, Finance authorizes, Payroll processes.

cards.definition: Analysis of total compensation cost relative to revenue generated.
cards.whyItMatters: Key metric for evaluating sales efficiency and plan affordability.
cards.howItWorks: Total compensation ÷ Total revenue = Cost of sales %. Segment and trend.
cards.example: Q4 analysis: $15M comp cost, $100M revenue = 15% cost of sales. Up from 13% in Q3. Investigate drivers.

cards.definition: Modeling the impact of proposed plan changes on cost and behavior before implementation.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables data-driven plan design decisions.
cards.howItWorks: Load historical data → Apply proposed rules → Calculate projected outcomes → Compare scenarios.
cards.example: Simulation: Adding 10% accelerator above quota. Projected cost increase: $1.5M. Projected performance lift: 8%.

cards.definition: The ability for sales reps to access compensation information from mobile devices.
cards.whyItMatters: Field reps need access anywhere; drives engagement and transparency.
cards.howItWorks: Mobile-responsive design or native app → Secure authentication → Real-time data → Offline capability.
cards.example: Rep checks commission on phone after closing deal. Sees updated earnings within minutes of CRM entry.

cards.definition: Automated routing and processing of compensation-related tasks and approvals.
cards.whyItMatters: Reduces manual effort and ensures consistent process execution.
cards.howItWorks: Define workflow rules → Trigger on events → Route to appropriate parties → Track progress → Escalate if needed.
cards.example: Exception request submitted → Auto-routed to manager → If >$10K, escalates to director → SLA tracked → Reminder sent.
